headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the CME Group Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. John Peschier. Please go ahead, sir
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the CME Group Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. John Peschier. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and thank you all for joining us today. Craig Donohue, our CEO; and Jamie Parisi, our CFO will spend a few minutes outlining the highlights of the fourth quarter and then we will open up the call for your questions. Also joining us for participati
componenttext: Thanks, and thank you all for joining us today. Craig Donohue, our CEO; and Jamie Parisi, our CFO will spend a few minutes outlining the highlights of the fourth quarter and then we will open up the call for your questions. Also joining us for participation in Q&A today are Terry Duffy, our Executive Chairman; Rick Redding, our Head of Product and Services, Phupinder Gill, our President; and Kim Taylor, our Head of Clearing. Before they begin, I'll read the Safe Harbor language. Statements made on this call and in the accompanying slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. These statements are not guarantees of future performance that involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements. More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance may be found in our filings with the SEC, including our most recent Forms 10-K and 10-Q, which are available in the CME website. During this call, we will refer to GAAP and non-GAAP pro forma results. A reconciliation is available in the press release and there is an accompanying file on the Investor Relations portion of our site, that provides detailed quarterly information on a GAAP and pro forma basis. With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Craig.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John and thank you for joining us this morning. There has been much said about the challenges of 2009, and CME Group certainly wasn't exempt from those challenges. However, looking back at the year, we are pleased with the progress CME Group has m
componenttext: Thanks, John and thank you for joining us this morning. There has been much said about the challenges of 2009, and CME Group certainly wasn't exempt from those challenges. However, looking back at the year, we are pleased with the progress CME Group has made, and the platform we built for the future. From the start of the year, through the end, we sought opportunities amongst the challenges and we were steadfast in pursuing and executing on those opportunities. I'm tremendously excited about how CME is currently positioned to pursue future growth. To highlight a few of our key accomplishments over the past year, we successfully integrated NYMEX and COMEX into CME Group. In addition to the strong recent growth trends in energy and metals volume, which I'll discuss in greater detail in a moment, we've been working on several statistics fronts to leverage these businesses. We've implemented global sales and marketing plans that include increased education and sales outreach to energy and metals customers, cross-selling across asset classes and extending our international intensive programs to these customers. We've completed the clearing and technology integration of NYMEX and COMEX, and achieved the full $60 million in run rate synergies. We've built on the success of the CME ClearPort platform by launching 332 new products in 2009, and we have plans under development to continue adding new asset classes. We've also scaled our technology for future growth. While exercising great expense discipline, we continued our ongoing focus on providing best-in-class technology by bringing on line a new state-of-the-art data center. As part of this effort, we migrated the FX and equities complexes to new match engines and customers have benefited from significant performance improvement. We will migrate other asset classes over the next year.The flexibility of the new data center positions us well for future volume growth, ongoing performance improvements and enhanced customer services. We see technology as helping us deliver better performance to our existing customers, as well as helping to attract new customers. As we have identified in the past, we are actively pursuing a broader global customer base. Over 2009, we made progress on several fronts and moving towards this goal. We worked on extending our global relevance by increasing the breadth of products we offer on Globex and developing key relationships with local regulators and market participants in several emerging geographies around the world. We continue to strengthen our BM&FBOVESPA partnership, launched the KOSPI 200 on Globex during non-Korean hours and signed an agreement with Bursa Malaysia to provide global order routing and matching services for their derivatives business, which will also provide us with a license to use their crude palm-oil settlement prices for future product development. We are very pleased with the success we've seen with these partnerships, and we believe they provide us with a strong base to aggressively market the full suite of CME Group products in those geographies. We are focused on positioning ourselves around the world to serve the customers of today, as well as the customers of tomorrow. As a measure of our global penetration, we increased our non-U.S. trading hours volume to 19% in the fourth quarter, up from 17% in the third quarter. While it is difficult to track precisely, we attribute much of this growth to targeted sales efforts in Europe and Asia. Finally, on the over-the-counter front, we initiated the pre-launch of over-the-counter cleared credit default swaps in December with eight dealer founding members and six buy-side founding members. We continue to actively work on several tracks to complete the steps necessary for our public launch targeted for the end of the first quarter. Most importantly, we see the progress there as a strong foundation for the long-term success of other over-the-counter offerings. Beyond all that I’ve just described, we were also hard at work managing the core business and in spite of the difficult climate, saw significant improvements there. Total open interest at CME Group grew from $63 million at the start of 2009 to $78 million at year end, an improvement of 24%. January has seen continued growth to $85 million. Interest-rate volumes were the most heavily affected by the credit crisis. Over the course of the year, we saw volume growth of 14% from the first quarter to the fourth quarter. More recently, January 2010 interest rate average daily volume of 4.8 million contracts is up 33% from January 2009.Several macroeconomic factors that drive interest rates have stabilized over the course of the year, including improvements in liquidity and credit spreads, but areas of weakness remain. The upcoming announced exit of the Fed from its mortgage-backed securities purchase program and its winding down of several temporary liquidity facilities are both a vote of confidence in the metrics that indicate a recovery is underway and a welcome step from markets that are eager to function based on fundamentals. It is difficult to predict timing, but these and other improving factors contribute to a more active interest rate environment. With macroeconomic factors beyond our control, we continue to work closely with customers on new product development, and we are pleased with the success of our most recent launch, the Ultra T Bond futures [Ultra Treasury Bond futures]. This is the most successful new interest-rate product launched in CME history in terms of volume and open-interest growth since launch. Open interest currently exceeds 40,000 contracts, and we've seen very good volume participation across multiple customer types using these products for a variety of needs. All of these factors bode well for our ability to grow this product over the long term. Equities volume showed strength early in 2009, as lack of liquidity in other asset classes and high volatility drove volume, but were challenged by declining volatility during the third and fourth quarters. A return of volatility over the last two weeks of January brought volumes to 3.5 million contracts during that time period, up 67% from volumes in the first half of January. The fourth quarter was a record quarter for energy, FX and metals volumes, which were up 21%, 57% and 59%, respectively from the third quarter. All of these product areas continued to show robust volumes in January as well. Beyond our core business and strategic growth initiatives, the other key area of focus for management in 2010 continues to be working with our regulators to ensure that derivatives markets retain their hallmarks of effective price discovery, safety and security. Before concluding, I would like to touch briefly on the status of ELX's attempt to a rule filing with the CFTC to compel CBOT to create or liquidate open positions without any corresponding transaction permitted by CBOT rules. The CFTC has not required us to take any action or modify our rules. I want to make absolutely clear that CBOT's rules remain in full force and effect, and that CBOT and CME Clearing have not been directed to accept directions from ELX or any of its members to open, liquidate or transfer positions in accordance with ELX's rule.We are engaged in a dialogue with the CFTC regarding CBOT's rationale for its long-standing rules prohibiting these types of transaction. As always, we are working closely with the commission staff. We have and continue to take these issues seriously, and are confident that the CBOT is operating in strict compliance with its statutory self-regulatory responsibilities and the requirement of the commodity exchange act. Given the ongoing nature of our discussions with the CFTC, I do not intend to make any further comments on this issue at this time, and when we thank you in advance for respecting that.There are a variety of other additional regulatory issues under consideration at the moment. CME Group appreciates the significance of the financial-markets crisis and the ensuing focus on market regulation. We believe our politicians and elected officials and regulators fundamentally recognize the value of transparent centrally-cleared markets, and that this recognition is reflected in much of the proposed legislation currently outstanding. In the aggregate, there are few areas of potential harm to our business and many areas that are potentially favorable for CME Group and other exchanges. As always, we continue to work to educate law makers and regulators on the forces that drive our markets, and how we can best maintain secure-efficient markets. In summary, in spite of all the challenges this past year, we successfully manage the aftermath of the credit crisis, and are now emerging well positioned for future growth. With fundamental market drivers achieving sustained stability, our core products are showing improvements in volume and open interest.  We have executed on the early stages of our over-the-counter clearing and global-expansion strategies, and we look forward to continuing to build these efforts for long-term success. With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Jamie to discuss our financial results.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Craig. CME Group turned in a strong fourth quarter financial performance, generating more revenue than any other quarter in 2009. Our GAAP results are summarized in the press release. Today, I'm going to focus on the details for Q4 on a pro for
componenttext: Thank you, Craig. CME Group turned in a strong fourth quarter financial performance, generating more revenue than any other quarter in 2009. Our GAAP results are summarized in the press release. Today, I'm going to focus on the details for Q4 on a pro forma basis. During Q4, average-daily volume was down 1% compared to the fourth quarter 2008 to 10.2 million contracts per day. We generated $667 million in revenue, and operating expenses were up 6% from the prior quarter, slightly less than we guided to on our last call. This resulted in $409 million of operating income and diluted earnings per share of $3.37.In terms of customer segmentation, we saw numbers for the fourth quarter remain largely in line with third quarter results. Proprietary buy-side traders contributed 43% of overall volume; hedge funds accounted for 8% of volume, showing a slight increase in contribution for the third quarter in a row; bank trading accounted for 13% of volume; other member activity, 20% and non-member activity, 16%. This segmentation is for legacy CME CBOT products only. We will be providing more details for the entire CME Group product suite beginning next quarter. The overall pro forma rate per contract for all CME Group volume decreased 2% to $0.849 compared with $0.866 in the fourth quarter 2008, primarily due to lower priced interest rate volume increasing from 36% of total a year ago to 43% this quarter. Sequentially, the rate per contract increased $0.015 from $0.834 to $0.849 due to a 1% increase in the metals proportion of the product mix, and a favorable pricing impact from changes implemented in August and September of 2009.Market data revenue of $82 million for the quarter decreased 6% versus last year and was up 1% sequentially. At the end of the fourth quarter, users subscribe to 396,000 base devices across CME, CBOT and NYMEX, down 9% versus Q4 of last year and down 1% sequentially. During Q4, we had a benefit from a billing adjustment which resulted in a positive sequential revenue growth. We have announced a professional screen fee increase from $55 to $61 per month beginning in January of 2010.I'll now take a few minutes to review expenses. Total pro forma operating expenses were $258 million for Q4, down 2% versus Q4 last year, but up $14 million or 6% sequentially. Total expense for the year was $998 million, down 8% as we delivered the NYMEX-related synergies and ratcheted down our discretionary expenses. Drilling into Q4 expenses, compensation and benefits was up $4 million sequentially to $88.6 million, due primarily to higher stock-based compensation. Stock-based compensation was $9.9 million in the fourth quarter, up $3 million from Q3. We moved our stock option grant date from mid-June to mid-September, and some prior-year grants rolled off in June, resulting in lower Q3 expense. Our combined headcount at the end of Q4 stood at 2,260, up slightly relative to the prior quarter. Our fourth quarter bonus expense was $11.8 million and for the full year, the bonus expense totaled $39 million, down 13% versus 2008. Non-compensation expenses of $170 million were down $6 million versus last year and up $10 million sequentially. Comparing to last quarter, the primary increases were in the professional fees line, up $4.7 million due to fees associated with our strategic initiatives and miscellaneous litigation and in the other expense line, up $4.4 million due to increased marketing costs, primarily related to sponsored conferences and currency fluctuation.Q4 pro forma operating income was $409 million, the high-water mark for 2009. During the fourth quarter, we were able to maintain a very strong pro forma operating margin of 61%, and we finished the full year with an operating margin of 62% compared to 64% in 2008. We view this as a significant achievement in light of the challenging environment throughout last year. In the non-operating income and expense category, on the investment income line, we received a $5 million dividend from the BM&FBOVESPA in line with Q3. During Q4, we paid down $225 million in debt and as of the end of December, we had $2.3 billion of debt outstanding and $303 million of cash and marketable securities. Interest expense totaled $30.7 million in Q4. During the quarter, we continued to pay down our debt by rolling less commercial paper, which carries a rate of less than 0.3% in the quarter. We expect our interest expense to remain at a similar level to Q4 for the next two quarters.After paying off $900 million of debt during the year, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio was down to 1.2%. Looking forward, we have a $300 million payment due in August, and we intend to pay off the remaining debt instruments on their maturity dates. The detail related to our debt structure is included in our earnings slide presentation on the website. For the quarter, our pro forma effective tax rate was 41.2%, bringing us to 41.1% for the year. Looking to 2010, we expect an effective tax rate of between 41% and 42%. Capital expenditures, net of leasehold improvement allowances, totaled $43 million in the fourth quarter and $137 million in 2009, driven primarily by data center, software, equipment and facilities costs.At this point, I would like to provide some insight and guidance related to our plans for 2010. First, on operating expenses, our normal growth rate from 2001 to 2007 was 8% to 10%. In 2008, our pro forma expenses dropped 2%, followed by an 8% drop in 2009 during a period in which we benefited from the synergies captured on our recent mergers, and we compressed discretionary spending as far as we could, including some items which are one-time in nature. As the economy shows signs of emerging from the recession, our outlook on growth is improving in 2010. We expect to return to more normal expense-growth levels, resulting in annual 2010 expense of approximately $1.1 billion.Within compensation, after holding salaries flat in 2009, we expect a 5% increase due to merit and promotion adjustments for employees, and to the impact of new hires. In terms of stock-based comp, we expect a similar quarterly run rate as we saw in Q4 of approximately $10 million to $11 million per quarter. Lastly, our bonus expense totaled $39 million in 2009, down from $45 million in 2008.  Looking ahead to 2010, our target-employee bonus is approximately $54 million, based on reaching our internal 2010 cash-earnings target. If our cash earnings for the year are 20% above our cash-earnings target, employee bonuses would be approximately $82 million. If we are more than 20% below our target, the bonus would be a minimal amount for non-exempt employees. The non-comp expense increase from 2009 is expected to come in many of the technology-oriented expenses, as we are aggressively building out our new data center. In addition, marketing and other expense is expected to rise during 2010 to roughly $23 million a quarter, on average, and is likely to be more front-end loaded. This higher level is attributable to advertising, promotion and travel expenses driven by our desire to expand both our global reach and our OTC capabilities. Licensing and fee sharing will likely rise based on continued growth in our Energy and Equity businesses. As always, during 2010, we will continue to spend on growth. We anticipate deploying additional OTC products, bringing the European clearing house online during the year and working on various other strategic initiatives. Turning to capital expenditures, as I mentioned earlier, we spent $137 million in 2009, well below our original 2009 guidance, and down from $205 million in 2008. In 2010, we anticipate between $180 million and $200 million of capital expenditures, driven by technology-related projects, as we now populate our new data center. In summary, we are proud of our results during a challenging year. We made incremental progress during 2009 after a fairly large shock to the financial system. We were very careful on expenses and at the same time, we continued to make investments in growth as reflected in our signing of various global partnerships, and laying the groundwork for a significant OTC clearing opportunity. And finally, we are optimistic about the strong start to 2010 with January volume averaging 11.2 million contracts per day, up 19% versus January 2009. We'll now open up the call for your questions. But in order to get to everyone, we are limiting all of you to one question and one follow-up, and then please feel free to get back in the queue if time permits.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Roger Freeman of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go first to Roger Freeman of Barclays Capital.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, on the proposed rule set from the CFTC, around position. Well it does sounds like it kind of came out in the range of what you had been arguing for, and I guess the question there is, do you have an estimate on, if you kind of look at deal
componenttext: I guess, first, on the proposed rule set from the CFTC, around position. Well it does sounds like it kind of came out in the range of what you had been arguing for, and I guess the question there is, do you have an estimate on, if you kind of look at dealer product trading, some large hedge funds that run regularly above the kind of what they leave on us today, what kind of volume impact you think that'll ultimately have, given these actual numbers they put up?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Roger, it's Craig. We're still in the process of examining the CFTC's proposal. I think that in general, the commission has done a good job of taking feedback and input variety of sources within the industry from the time that they first have their hearin
componenttext: Roger, it's Craig. We're still in the process of examining the CFTC's proposal. I think that in general, the commission has done a good job of taking feedback and input variety of sources within the industry from the time that they first have their hearings at the convention [ph] in the fall. There's a lot of complexity and various aspects of their proposal, which we and other market participants are still digesting. And I'm expecting that not only CME Group, but certainly others will be taking the opportunity to comment rather extensively on those proposals. In general, at the moment, I do think it's not likely that the proposals, we understand them, will have any kind of significant impact on trading volumes or open interest, and so from that perspective, we're viewing that favorably. But as I mentioned, there's a deal of complexity in the proposals, and we're still digesting that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess my second question, just be around CDS volumes. So I know you're sort of in a soft launch phase. There was an initial burst of activity sort of mid-December, kind of looks like the dealers are trying to just check off the box to sort of m
componenttext: And then I guess my second question, just be around CDS volumes. So I know you're sort of in a soft launch phase. There was an initial burst of activity sort of mid-December, kind of looks like the dealers are trying to just check off the box to sort of meet the deadline, and there really hasn't been much since. I mean, are there still sort of issues outstanding with the dealers that need to be addressed from a clearing perspective, to kind of move the ball forward there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Kim. We are in the middle of a [indiscernible] as you mentioned. We are working with the dealers on a -- on plans for the launch schedule to expand the set of products and the set of customers who would be able to participate. So I think we are on
componenttext: This is Kim. We are in the middle of a [indiscernible] as you mentioned. We are working with the dealers on a -- on plans for the launch schedule to expand the set of products and the set of customers who would be able to participate. So I think we are on target for doing that within the first quarter, but we have not kind of ramped up that process yet.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mike Vinciquerra, BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mike Vinciquerra, BMO Capital Markets.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: First thing, just on the energy space, two things there I guess. WTI has, I guess been the weak contract in terms of looking at oil and nat [natural] gas and whatnot trading early this year. Any particular reason you guys feel like that product has had a
componenttext: First thing, just on the energy space, two things there I guess. WTI has, I guess been the weak contract in terms of looking at oil and nat [natural] gas and whatnot trading early this year. Any particular reason you guys feel like that product has had a little less success than maybe Brent and some of the others? And then tied to that, there's a lot of noise around the Argus crude contract and we haven't heard any update, is that contract out there in trading at all these days?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Rick. No, WTI has actually been a fairly strong performer. I mean, if you look in the fourth quarter and even into January, it's one of those areas with the macroeconomic conditions the way they are, people are trading that a lot. So I just
componenttext: Mike, this is Rick. No, WTI has actually been a fairly strong performer. I mean, if you look in the fourth quarter and even into January, it's one of those areas with the macroeconomic conditions the way they are, people are trading that a lot. So I just want to be careful on your statement. As far as the Argus sour products, both CME and ICE have launched products there. Not doing anything at this stage because I mean as we've been saying, it will take a while for those benchmarks to gain some acceptance. What we have done though is some of the components within the index actually are trading, the Mars product in particular. So pretty much what we said would happen is happening, and we continue to look forward as the industry evolves or how it moves. I mean again, remember, Mike, that all this stuff is based off WTI pricing. So it actually is probably pretty favorable for our WTI business.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just your early success with the ultra bond future, any sense for how broad the potential user base is there? Is it as broad as it is for all the other treasury products?
componenttext: And then just your early success with the ultra bond future, any sense for how broad the potential user base is there? Is it as broad as it is for all the other treasury products?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've gotten off to a great start there. I mean in three weeks -- I mean in the history of the futures world, you're hard pressed to find anything that's done this well. Part of it has been obviously, we’ve listened to the marketplace. We've adopte
componenttext: Yes, we've gotten off to a great start there. I mean in three weeks -- I mean in the history of the futures world, you're hard pressed to find anything that's done this well. Part of it has been obviously, we’ve listened to the marketplace. We've adopted our product development to the credit crisis. And this was the product the market needed, because the duration of all these instruments has come in quite a bit given the rate environment. This has actually been broadly used by both buying and sell side at this point. And the other thing that is encouraging is as we thought, we see people also spreading this against the 30-year Treasury bond. So this has just been a phenomenal uptake in the product. And one of the good things, as Craig mentioned, that 44,000-plus of open interest, over 5,000 of it is already in the June contract. So you're starting to see people already think about the future and what that contract will hold.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Howard Chen of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Howard Chen of Crédit Suisse.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not sure if you have these stats handy, Rick, but was curious if we could get any update on the current depth-of-book stats that you’ve shared in the past as clearly the market tone and activity levels have improved a lot.
componenttext: Not sure if you have these stats handy, Rick, but was curious if we could get any update on the current depth-of-book stats that you’ve shared in the past as clearly the market tone and activity levels have improved a lot.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have been looking at those, Howard. And both -- in December, what you actually see across almost every product, even compared to September, you've seen depths of books increase anywhere from 10% to 60%. What you see is the -- even things in like T
componenttext: Yes, we have been looking at those, Howard. And both -- in December, what you actually see across almost every product, even compared to September, you've seen depths of books increase anywhere from 10% to 60%. What you see is the -- even things in like Treasury complex, which was really affected by the crisis, what you do see is the depth of the book actually coming back to pre-crisis levels. You've also seen the average bid-ask spread come in quite a bit in especially, in some of the financial products for large-sized contracts, you actually again see these kind of at pre-crisis levels. So we're very encouraged of where the liquidity is in these markets, given the amount of destruction that occurred early in 2009.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Jamie, my follow up, just on the numbers, the commentary that interest expense levels stay near the current levels for the next two quarters, does that imply you temporarily like stop the debt paydown? And is the thought to just hoard a bit more
componenttext: And then Jamie, my follow up, just on the numbers, the commentary that interest expense levels stay near the current levels for the next two quarters, does that imply you temporarily like stop the debt paydown? And is the thought to just hoard a bit more cash now?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Howard, it's really just a function of how the maturities lay out. So there's only a little bit left on the commercial paper to paydown and then we do have a maturity in the third quarter in August that will be accumulating, so we can pay that down.
componenttext: Howard, it's really just a function of how the maturities lay out. So there's only a little bit left on the commercial paper to paydown and then we do have a maturity in the third quarter in August that will be accumulating, so we can pay that down.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: But just to follow up on that briefly, Jamie, is there a prepayment penalty for what's due in August?
componenttext: But just to follow up on that briefly, Jamie, is there a prepayment penalty for what's due in August?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: What's due in August is a public issue so there's no prepayment clause on that. The only piece that does have a prepayment ability on it is the bank loan that I believe is due next August in 2011. So that's the only piece that we are able to prepay and if
componenttext: What's due in August is a public issue so there's no prepayment clause on that. The only piece that does have a prepayment ability on it is the bank loan that I believe is due next August in 2011. So that's the only piece that we are able to prepay and if we do prepay it, we do have hedges outstanding where we did fix the rates, so there is a cost associated with unwinding those hedges. So it doesn't necessarily make sense for us to do that immediately. So someday, we continue to analyze as conditions change.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Rich Repetto, Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: We'll go next to Rich Repetto, Sandler O'Neill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess staying on the expense theme here a little bit. Jamie, your marketing and other expenses are $23 million average per quarter. So if you annualize that, it's $92 million. And I guess it looks like a pretty big $35 million, $37 million increase year
componenttext: I guess staying on the expense theme here a little bit. Jamie, your marketing and other expenses are $23 million average per quarter. So if you annualize that, it's $92 million. And I guess it looks like a pretty big $35 million, $37 million increase year-over-year. I know '09, that line had some one-time, so it's not a fair, totally fair comparison, but it is an uptick. I know you mentioned OTC, but can you give us a little bit more, deeper color there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, first, if you look at the overall picture right, the marketing expense in '08, a year just where we're leading into the crisis at the end of the year, the marketing expense in '08 was about $22 million a quarter. So it's more reverting to that ki
componenttext: I think, first, if you look at the overall picture right, the marketing expense in '08, a year just where we're leading into the crisis at the end of the year, the marketing expense in '08 was about $22 million a quarter. So it's more reverting to that kind of more normalized level. And if you think about the projects or the strategy that we have outlined for everybody, globalizing the business and going after the OTC markets, you can imagine that there's quite a bit of marketing associated with that. And a lot of -- as we globalize, there's a lot of travel. So there's a lot of expense additional expenses associated with that. So it's not just marketing, it's marketing and other expense. The other thing to keep in mind is that within that category, we enjoyed some -- for the year in 2009, we enjoyed some favorable FX fluctuation, which we can assume for 2010.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up would be, I guess for Terry and Craig, the bulk of plan, when it was sort of announced to stock the exchange or, at least, yours and ICE got negatively impacted, and can you give us any update -- and based on your discussions, these are t
componenttext: And my follow-up would be, I guess for Terry and Craig, the bulk of plan, when it was sort of announced to stock the exchange or, at least, yours and ICE got negatively impacted, and can you give us any update -- and based on your discussions, these are the Congressmen or the administration on what you think the actual risk here is or maybe even your conversation with the dealers?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, I think that it's really premature for us to sort of speculate and comment on that. In that, as you know, I mean, they've introduced, I guess, a broad concept, but there is not yet any kind of specific proposal. And so I think it's awfully difficult
componenttext: Rich, I think that it's really premature for us to sort of speculate and comment on that. In that, as you know, I mean, they've introduced, I guess, a broad concept, but there is not yet any kind of specific proposal. And so I think it's awfully difficult for us to sort of project forward what the meaning and implications of that might be. So we're going to be looking at that very carefully, obviously, if and when that advances. But for the moment, I think it's difficult to speculate and it's not clear to us, at least at this point, that that's going to have a meaningful impact on us.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Rich, just to add just a little bit to what Craig said, he said it in his prepared remarks earlier, there is a lot of pending legislation both out of the House bills on ag and financial services that we see that are potential very favorable to us goi
componenttext: And, Rich, just to add just a little bit to what Craig said, he said it in his prepared remarks earlier, there is a lot of pending legislation both out of the House bills on ag and financial services that we see that are potential very favorable to us going forward. So we're going to be out there a lot and we're going to continue to work on the pending legislation and anything else that comes up.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was just trying to see whether you had any insight from -- I know you have strong relationships down there, but I understand.
componenttext: I was just trying to see whether you had any insight from -- I know you have strong relationships down there, but I understand.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: It is preliminary.
componenttext: It is preliminary.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rich, if you look at the volume breakdown, right, we said that the banks are around 13% or so of the trading. When you look at it from a revenue perspective, it's significantly less than that because they're paying the lowest fees, right [indiscernible].
componenttext: Rich, if you look at the volume breakdown, right, we said that the banks are around 13% or so of the trading. When you look at it from a revenue perspective, it's significantly less than that because they're paying the lowest fees, right [indiscernible]. So when you look at it from a revenue perspective, it's in the 8% to 9% range. And then you look at that again and you say, "Of that trading that they're doing, how much of it is true speculative trading versus how much it is hedging their book?" so you hair cut that yet again. So we don't have specific numbers, but you can see that the number gets cut down pretty significantly as you start thinking through it.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Niamh Alexander, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
componenttext: We'll go next to Niamh Alexander, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to the paying down of the debt and getting to the 1.2 debt-to-EBITDA and then getting even lower later in the year, how should we think about all that cash that you're generating? Would you maybe be looking to prioritize inorganic growth over
componenttext: With regards to the paying down of the debt and getting to the 1.2 debt-to-EBITDA and then getting even lower later in the year, how should we think about all that cash that you're generating? Would you maybe be looking to prioritize inorganic growth over maybe repurchases? Can you kind of update us on what your thoughts are there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you look out, we do have maturity scheduled out over the next several years, and we'll be building cash in advance of those maturities to be able to paydown those maturities, I think, is the way to think about it for now. Of course, we continue to alwa
componenttext: As you look out, we do have maturity scheduled out over the next several years, and we'll be building cash in advance of those maturities to be able to paydown those maturities, I think, is the way to think about it for now. Of course, we continue to always be vigilant regarding our capital structure and we analyze it all the time.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we should think about -- you can afford to carry the debt with the cash you're generating, but we should assume that you're going to continue to just pay it down, right?
componenttext: So we should think about -- you can afford to carry the debt with the cash you're generating, but we should assume that you're going to continue to just pay it down, right?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Operating margin, is it feasible to think about, Jamie, getting back to like 65%, 66% operating margin as the volumes kind of grow, because the open interest is certainly pointing in the right direction? Is it maybe something that we'd need to see more of
componenttext: Operating margin, is it feasible to think about, Jamie, getting back to like 65%, 66% operating margin as the volumes kind of grow, because the open interest is certainly pointing in the right direction? Is it maybe something that we'd need to see more of a step function, I don't know, like 2012 when you may not necessarily have to stay in New York anymore? How should we think about the operating margin potential?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. First I'd like to say I was really very proud of how the exchange operated in 2009, being able to hold the 62% margin given the environment that we're operating in. Looking forward and if you look back at our history as we've been able to add volumes
componenttext: Yes. First I'd like to say I was really very proud of how the exchange operated in 2009, being able to hold the 62% margin given the environment that we're operating in. Looking forward and if you look back at our history as we've been able to add volumes to the platform, certainly, there's a lot of operating leverage in our model. And I would expect that if we're able to add those volumes, that there could be potential margin expansion. Niamh, if I would just add to that, by the way, that obviously we're committed to New York. I mean, it's a significant place of business for us. We do plan to continue to maintain the Oppenheimer[ph] ((49:18) private trading facilities there, so long as they're profitable and we have a very significant employee base, which we expect to remain there. So I just want to make that clarification.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Dan Fannon of Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go to Dan Fannon of Jefferies.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Building on that question a little bit, can you guys prioritize where you see the most opportunity for growth? I mean, obviously you have the OTC initiatives. But are you also evaluating potential bolt-on acquisitions that are -- some which are being rumo
componenttext: Building on that question a little bit, can you guys prioritize where you see the most opportunity for growth? I mean, obviously you have the OTC initiatives. But are you also evaluating potential bolt-on acquisitions that are -- some which are being rumored over the last couple of weeks in the news?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well,, I mean, obviously, we've got, I think, the diverse and broad growth strategy, as you can tell from our discussion and the highlighting of our continued product innovation and enhancements of our technology and clearing capabilities. We're continuin
componenttext: Well,, I mean, obviously, we've got, I think, the diverse and broad growth strategy, as you can tell from our discussion and the highlighting of our continued product innovation and enhancements of our technology and clearing capabilities. We're continuing to focus very strongly on core growth in our core businesses. We obviously also have a number of very important non-core growth initiatives, including as you mentioned, the over-the-counter derivatives clearing services area. And then obviously, globalization is an important part of that, in both respects. So we have always a view toward how we can expand the range of products and services that we provide to our clients, and to create value for customers. So non-organic growth opportunities are always going to be something that we look at, but beyond that, I have no specific comment.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Michael Carrier, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go to Michael Carrier, Deutsche Bank.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jamie, just on the expenses. You're obviously investing on the business, just given everything that you guys are working on makes sense. But when you think about the level of the $1.1 billion, I know it's hard to say, but in terms of volumes and what you'
componenttext: Jamie, just on the expenses. You're obviously investing on the business, just given everything that you guys are working on makes sense. But when you think about the level of the $1.1 billion, I know it's hard to say, but in terms of volumes and what you're expecting, where are we at like currently and for the year? Like how much flexibility and volumes were to slide or you don't get the increase on, say, the interest rate products?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think -- I'm not going to get specific around volumes as you know, but if you look back at last year, I think it's pretty instructive, hopefully, that we had some flexibility in there. When you look at -- if the business isn't performing, the expense na
componenttext: I think -- I'm not going to get specific around volumes as you know, but if you look back at last year, I think it's pretty instructive, hopefully, that we had some flexibility in there. When you look at -- if the business isn't performing, the expense naturally flexes. And you've seen us pull back when we need to on the discretionary expenses. So I think we've demonstrated that we're capable of doing that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any update in terms of timing for the European clearing house and/or, let's say, like an interest rate swap solution?
componenttext: Any update in terms of timing for the European clearing house and/or, let's say, like an interest rate swap solution?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would ask the European clearing house for that question. We continue to work with the FSA, the regulator in the U.K., and moving to a recognition process. We are making progress for that process, but I can't really give you a definitive timeframe on a r
componenttext: I would ask the European clearing house for that question. We continue to work with the FSA, the regulator in the U.K., and moving to a recognition process. We are making progress for that process, but I can't really give you a definitive timeframe on a regulatory process. We've made good progress on building up the team there. And we look forward to being able to launch the services relatively soon after a TV [ph] recognition.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the interest rate swaps, we continue to make good progress working with buy and sell side to provide a solution there. Obviously, the CDS initiative we have going on is helping us speed the further [ph] products up as they come along. So we're making g
componenttext: On the interest rate swaps, we continue to make good progress working with buy and sell side to provide a solution there. Obviously, the CDS initiative we have going on is helping us speed the further [ph] products up as they come along. So we're making good progress.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ken Worthington, JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ken Worthington, JPMorgan.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, the Fed has announced the expiration of a number of lending guarantee and purchase programs over the next couple of months. Are there any programs that are ending that you think could have a meaningful impact on the business? And if so, could you k
componenttext: First, the Fed has announced the expiration of a number of lending guarantee and purchase programs over the next couple of months. Are there any programs that are ending that you think could have a meaningful impact on the business? And if so, could you kind of walk through how you see things playing out?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what has been announced, Ken, is especially related to the mortgage back area, the mortgage area. It's not 100% clear if they're just going to stop or face some other kind of program [ph] [indiscernible]. I think it's a little difficult to say how
componenttext: I think what has been announced, Ken, is especially related to the mortgage back area, the mortgage area. It's not 100% clear if they're just going to stop or face some other kind of program [ph] [indiscernible]. I think it's a little difficult to say how that's going to unfold. However, what is positive for us is as those kind of market rates come back into the environment, that's probably a good catalyst for interest rate movement. And obviously, the need for people to hedge also moving away from the government providing that back stop[ph] (54:00) will force private industry, private banks to step up and be a bigger part of this as well as the GSE. So in that, you're probably looking at a more volatile rate environment or at least rates going back to where some people think they should be and not artificially depressed. So depending on how they do it, you could see a lot more activity for some of our clients.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll try to walk the fine line here. With regard to competition, have your thoughts evolved on how you're dealing with competition today versus maybe how CME and CBOT dealt with life in Eurex in the past? The reason for my question is it seems like defend
componenttext: I'll try to walk the fine line here. With regard to competition, have your thoughts evolved on how you're dealing with competition today versus maybe how CME and CBOT dealt with life in Eurex in the past? The reason for my question is it seems like defending your market position and being anti-competitive, the line between the two may have narrowed under the current administration and maybe -- just what are your thoughts there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think anything is different. I mean, we've lived in a highly competitive, innovative, dynamic industry for certainly the last 30 to 40 years. We have a broad space of competitors that trade very substantially identical products, similar prod
componenttext: Well, I don't think anything is different. I mean, we've lived in a highly competitive, innovative, dynamic industry for certainly the last 30 to 40 years. We have a broad space of competitors that trade very substantially identical products, similar products, products that are economic substitutes for our own, not just in exchange traded, but also over-the-counter markets. And so we continue to compete aggressively on the basis of the quality of our products and services and the strength of our customer relationships. The strength of our technology, the strength of our clearing house and on our innovation capabilities. And I think that's not different from the past, and I think that'll be different in the future.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you think of aggressive competition presents longer-term risks or is it just good business?
componenttext: Do you think of aggressive competition presents longer-term risks or is it just good business?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do I think what?
componenttext: Do I think what?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Like aggressive tactics, do aggressive tactics present longer-term risks that may not have been present in the past?
componenttext: Like aggressive tactics, do aggressive tactics present longer-term risks that may not have been present in the past?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't remember any competitors in the past being particularly polite or passive. So -- I mean, if you look at the history of competition in this industry, it tends to be incredibly aggressive. And I think we've demonstrated over a long period of time th
componenttext: I don't remember any competitors in the past being particularly polite or passive. So -- I mean, if you look at the history of competition in this industry, it tends to be incredibly aggressive. And I think we've demonstrated over a long period of time that we are equally a very formidable and strong competitor. And the strength of our position is based on the fact that we've been very innovative. We offer extremely high-quality liquidity in markets and services. And we've made very substantial investments that have been very valuable to us since we've built our business.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go to the Jonathan Casteleyn of Susquehanna Brokerage.
componenttext: We'll go to the Jonathan Casteleyn of Susquehanna Brokerage.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question for Rick, you just mentioned it briefly, but within the interest rate futures complex, is it change in aftermarket yields, is it enough to really drive strong volume growth going forward? Or do we really need the Fed to kind of move benchmark rat
componenttext: Question for Rick, you just mentioned it briefly, but within the interest rate futures complex, is it change in aftermarket yields, is it enough to really drive strong volume growth going forward? Or do we really need the Fed to kind of move benchmark rates around?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you have to look at it two ways, Jonathan. On the short end of the curve clearly, you need to get out of the zero-interest rate policy to really change the dynamic there. You can look at [indiscernible] some futures market to see where the m
componenttext: Well, I think you have to look at it two ways, Jonathan. On the short end of the curve clearly, you need to get out of the zero-interest rate policy to really change the dynamic there. You can look at [indiscernible] some futures market to see where the market thinks those rates are going to substantially move before the end of the year. On the longer end of the curve, though, outside of the short rates, there's a lot that's going on in the mortgage market, a lot that's going on there, a lot of the government policies, a lot of that can move without having the zero-interest rate policy change at all. So I mean, the other thing to think about there, Jonathan, is as those relationships across the yield curve may change, based on how the government exits this program. So it's harder to do a point estimate of volatility, but the way we think about it is looking at it as the shape of the yield curve also may change here as well.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: So longer-term contracts could benefit, but definitely the short end would definitely benefit more so by a Fed underlying benchmark change?
componenttext: So longer-term contracts could benefit, but definitely the short end would definitely benefit more so by a Fed underlying benchmark change?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think, Jonathan, if you look at the increase in volume in Q4 and [indiscernible] what you see is the Treasury complex has a bigger rate of increase than euro-dollar complex, which I think is indicative of that. What you do see on the short
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think, Jonathan, if you look at the increase in volume in Q4 and [indiscernible] what you see is the Treasury complex has a bigger rate of increase than euro-dollar complex, which I think is indicative of that. What you do see on the short end of the curve in the euro-dollar complex is the back 32 contracts are actually year-on-year volumes up quite significantly. So you're starting to see people and have seen people position a little further out in the curve on where they think rate movement will take place.
